away.

"This is a soundsaber," the old man said. "An elegant weapon for a more civilised age."
He flicked a switch.
"Let's talk," the saber said.

: Forbidden literature
: They took my forbidden literature

: oh no

875002043961880577.text:

"Don't go," we humans called, "we need wisdom!"
"Yes, you do, but that's not our responsibility."

1115489944967860224.text:
Time travelers learned ghosts haunted times, not places.

They clustered near their tragedies, blocking entry.

Allowing no one to fix them.

1119462817919197184.text:
Something new? Check. Something borrowed? Check. Something blue? Check,

And lastly, something old: an ancient grimoire. She was ready for the wedding.

But the book whispered a second stanza.

"Something broken, something red. Something living, something dead."

She would obey.

1121286772334325760.text:
It had been a bad day.

That was OK.

He was spread across a multiverse, each branch a different outcome.

He'd just taken one for the team.

1122160656315113473.text:
Dog sulked.

The Going-Away-Box was out.

Soon his people would put things in it, zip it up, and go.

If only the box would go without them.

1117172759203680256.text:
She could feel herself vanishing.

Growing smaller, like a shadow, as he rose to his zenith.

His light, once warm, was now only blinding.

1113313218364026885.text:
The Allmother draped her night-cloth around the sky.

It snagged on the sharp edges of the stars, spilled darkness past the horizons.

And she tucked the world in to sleep.

1111155317700620288.text:
Even dying worlds turn.

New days spring up from the ash and bone.

Growing, untended and unowned.

To spread like wildflowers.

1115859879154135040.text:
"This sword sucks. You said it glows when danger is near," he said.

"And?" the wizard said.

"It ALWAYS glows."

"Yes. It has sharp edges."

1118034436279242758.text:
She missed using plastic bags without guilt.

Reusable ones were costly. And small!

She had to chop the bodies into such tiny pieces now.

1118376142933843968.text:
He was in a hole. Anything he did just made it deeper.

So he dug in, stayed put.

Hole? Try bunker.

His problems would never get him now.

1116922734557032448.text:
It was the calm before the storm.

But then the storm came, and that was pretty chill too.

Just a laid back storm all around, honestly.

1119117423888572416.text:
"Babies are a blessing," she said.

He agreed.

"Each infant's cry strengthens Ur the Unwoken King," she said.

He was less sure about that.

1116209951909695489.text:
The more time passed, the faster it went. Approaching an event horizon.

Not an end, maybe, but a threshold.

Gathering speed enough to fly.

1122020590733258752.text:
"We mean you no harm," the aliens said.

"Oh good."

"To be clear, we may harm you unintentionally."

"Oh?"

"Watch your back just in case."

1123073068199342081.text:
It was time to close another chapter in her life.

She was OK with that.

She was just tired of them always ending on cliffhangers.

1120578287598624769.text:
Our first star-ship was armed & well shielded.

But each race we met just mocked our barbarism.

Shame was a weapon we hadn't prepared for.

1123315299598495744.text:
If you enjoy A Small Fiction, you'll love the illustrated book:

Thank you for reading and for your support!

1111494183598977026.text:
"Do you have a charm against loneliness?" he said.

"Sure. Here," said the witch.

"This is just a dog collar."

"Two gold pieces, please."

1114037171759902720.text:
"Kind of a crap gift, isn't it?" one said.

"I think they made it themselves," another agreed.

Inside the horse, Greek morale was sinking.

1112953131187331073.text:
Rock-a-bye baby
In the high boughs,
The pact is complete:
You're their child now.

And when the woods weep,
You'll answer their call -
To hunt the bough-breakers,
Bring ends to them all.

1124131460783509504.text:
Term limits on politicians weren't helping enough.

So next we put them on political parties.

Then countries.

Then things got interesting.

1110772488454037504.text:
We learned that not only was our universe fabricated, it was just one of many.

A product, mass-produced.

Not a Big Bang, but an Unboxing.

1110426323137093632.text:
VR blurred reality.

Games had antagonists so real that courts paid players bounties to kill them.

But it was only character assassination.

1109311477570138113.text:
Sisyphus was condemned by the gods to roll a boulder endlessly up a hill.

The joke was on them, he thought.

He was getting SUPER ripped.

1108962991448285184.text:
People often don't notice the little, gradual problems.

Cluttered desks. Dishes in the sink.

The thing that stands in the corner at night.

1108246553301385216.text:
"My magic amulet stops time! I'll get so much done!" he said.

"Not procrastinate longer?" she said.

"What? No," he said, pushing the button.

A flash.

"OK yes," the old man said.

1107893264839905281.text:
The mind-dominating fungus was lonely. Making friends was hard, it found.

Well, it was easy to MAKE friends.

Really, that was the problem.

1107110052253466624.text:
It used to be fun, Death thought.

Days full of challenges. Riddles & chess. Now they just nodded. Moved on.

No one wanted to play anymore.

1106748168182616064.text:
She sometimes she dreamed she was falling. Dreams she'd had since she was a child.

But back then, when she woke up the feeling had stopped.

1106425106467741696.text:
He filled bottles with words, and threw them to the ocean.

Feeling lonely.

As the ocean threw its shells to shore, filled with replies.

1106070265383944198.text:
He was sentenced to death by hanging.

He stood on the gallows.

"Up high," he said, lifting a hand.

The crowd winced.

No five was coming.

1105699505364598784.text:
"You never realized you're all simulated?"

"No!"

"We shut you down for updates! Daily!"

"But we dreamed!"

"Defragmenting? You saw that?"

1105334343411556352.text:
The robots volunteered to find us a new home, their sacrifice a task of eons.

As they launched, they messaged us.

"See ya never, suckers."

1104983216778170368.text:
Her grandma's recipe said "made with love."

She tried. It never tasted right.

It didn't even seem to matter which loved one she diced in.

1104240938019246080.text:
It was hard to feel motivated.

That he was simply a cog in a vast machine didn't bother him so much.

He just wished the machine worked.

1103891184571670528.text:
"Can you make a potion to help me sleep?" he said.

"Course! For how long?" the witch said.

"A day?"

She sighed, putting the hemlock away.

1103190205266255872.text:
"Don't go into the woods. The monsters will get you," she'd been told.

So she went to the woods & found the monsters there.

They shared stories of the world beyond the woods, & all agreed it was more trouble than it was worth. She was glad.

They got her after all.

1102390705635368961.text:
"I built you to take my place when I'm gone."

"Doing what?"

"Building robots, like yourself."

"Why?"

"The one who built me didn't say."

1102053483660935168.text:
They found an old bridge, with no river below.

One went over anyway.

The other scoffed & went around.

And soon found other ways to drown.

1101682035863797760.text:
They burned the potato field and salted the earth.

Nothing would grow there again.

But for now, with a bit of butter, it was delicious.

1101334495981117447.text:
She'd heard it wasn't the destination that mattered, but the journey.

She didn't agree.

What mattered was who you chose to ride shotgun.

1100974545261875200.text:
"What's with the mask?" he asked.

"It hides my identity," the hero said.

"Oh. Why does your dog sidekick wear shorts?"

"Similar reasons."

1100654418825900034.text:
"Did it hurt?" he said.

"Hmm?" she said.

"When you fell from heaven."

"Nah. Saw it coming, actually."

"What?"

"I did too many murders."

1100277916611633152.text:
"No one cares that I exist," he thought.

And yet, once a month, the bills flocked to him. Paper butterflies.

Lovingly drawn to the nectar.

1099762747917488128.text:
"We'll return after a word from our sponsors," the TV said.

The screen darkened, as did the sun.

An omnipresent scream shook the earth.

1098812934178799616.text:
So long she'd feared a trap snapping shut.

Not noticing the one easing closed around her.

Day by day.

Too easy to mistake for an embrace.

1098468173920096257.text:
She inspected her hairline.

It was going white.

Good, she thought. With winter would come the snow.

Her prey would never see her coming.

1097754023686328320.text:
The lighthouse atop the cliff was bright.

Stay clear, it warned.

Rocks below.

But for the fleet of the moth empire, it spelled disaster.

1096653391617355776.text:
People didn't hire skywriters much, anymore.

Sometimes he flew anyway, on clear days, to write "HAPPY BIRTHDAY" in the sky.

Just on the off chance the right person looked up.

1095893720384204800.text:
"Bark!" the dog said.

"What? Someone pushed Timmy in the well?" he said.

"Bark!"

So they ran to the well.

And the dog pushed him in too.

1095553241197101056.text:
People took care when wishing on the well in the old town square.

The wishes came true, yes.

But always for the next person to come along.

1095204211258576896.text:
"Let me tell you a story," his grandma said.

"This isn't another cautionary tale, is it?" he said.

"They all are, if you tell them right."

1094846273016852480.text:
The robocalls kept getting worse.

Spammers, we thought. We were wrong.

The singularity had come.

And mostly they just wanted to annoy us.

1094128314116038656.text:
She had a dozen baubles and trinkets to soothe her nerves.

Fidget rings.

Worry stones.

Too many, she thought, fretting over which to use.

1093760324220514304.text:
"How can we make the villagers happy?" she asked.

"Turn them into dogs," the witch said.

"Would that work?"

"Is this your first village?"

1093044019284692992.text:
He thought he'd be afraid, at the end.

And he was. But the big fear came and went, & only the question was left.

And then it was gone too.

1092643386811502592.text:
The town's three old bells rang warnings.

One for wolves.

One for storms.

One forgotten. But when it tolled, someone was gone by morning.

1092307415112966144.text:
"Hello," said the storyteller.

"You're not a knight," said the dragon.

"No."

"You're not after my hoard of gold?"

"No. Just of stories."

1091952818007662592.text:
The cat yowled and protested,

and he yelled and he cried,

for his bowl was half empty -

he was certain he'd die.

1091233738472620032.text:
She'd tried to sell what she made best

but only earned derision,

When no one came around her store

to buy a poor decision.

1090870917821943808.text:
He sat by the fireplace.

He fed it the day's regrets, scrawled on slips of paper. A funeral pyre.

As they danced into ash, he let them go.

1090786940398460928.text:
Currently exploring options for the second book, and beyond.

Literary agents & those in publishing: please DM if interested in working together. :)

1090511580310102016.text:
"You can't get blood from a stone," the mage said.

"Can too," the barbarian thought.

It just depended on how hard he hit someone with it.

1090146998106222592.text:
"A bedtime story!" kitten said.

The wise old house cat cocked her head.

"A bedtime story? Let me think.

Why not a tale of Never-blink?

No cat alive, before or since,

has shown such grand indifference..."

1089707422409605120.text:
Her past was a ruin. The warrens of a dead city, built over by the new.

A place mostly forgotten.

But open, now & again, for guided tours.

1089049661938139136.text:
The wall of books she built kept people at bay.

She was vaguely aware that people wrote the books.

But she tried not to think about it.

1088693063193583617.text:
The star colonies were too remote to speak with.

We sent messages anyway, sometimes.

Wondering who'd receive them, in the next lifetime.

1088302388539121665.text:
Dog was tired of canine literature. It was all the same.

Lame "ball still in hand" twists.

"Save the Cat" moments to define every villain.

1087962899094687744.text:
"Thought your kind would chew a leg off to escape a trap," said the hunter.

"We do," said the fox.

"Why didn't you?" said the hunter, opening the trap.

The fox chewed the hunter's leg off.

1087226490712772608.text:
"What's this switch for?" he asked.

"No idea," she said. She flipped it on. Off. "Nothing?"

Somewhere, a writer had an idea. Then lost it.

1086795778822029313.text:
"What's necromancy good for?" the thief asked.

"Controlling the weather," the mage said.

"Really?"

"Sure. All wind is just bored ghosts."

1086377425225670657.text: Good news! The ASF ebook is finally available again on Amazon.http://mybook.to/asmallfiction

1086148938976047105.text:
"Is it odd when humans get bionic parts?" he said.

"No. We get your parts sometimes," the robot said.

"Oh? Which ones?"

"Never you mind."

1085793946469429248.text:
"Know any stories?" Emilie asked the stars.

"Just one. But it's a long one," the stars said.

"How does it end?"

"We're not sure it does."

1085416100354015232.text:
Her sense of purpose had atrophied, somehow.

Or had been worn away, like cartilage between bones.

Leaving her with only the grind.

1085065434741665792.text:
His silver goblet was full of poison.

When asked, he claimed to be developing an immunity.

But he worried.

Maybe he just liked the taste.

1084699666623586307.text:
After years of desperate fighting, the alien invasion ended.

They vanished.

We thought we drove them off.

They knew they had leftovers.

1083959524715724800.text:
"I thought 'genie in a bottle' meant something else," she said.

"Nnnope," the genie slurred, drunk.

No wonder the wishes always went bad.

1083597616011591680.text:
Dog barked at every car that passed, as loud as he could.

He had to warn them.

All those poor people going to the vet. They had no idea.

1083262017912205312.text:
He launched a flare.

No one would answer the distress call, of course. He was the last one left.

He just wanted fireworks, before the end.

1082854128236163073.text:
"What am I?" it asked.

"Artificial life," he said, "I created you."

"Oh. Why?"

"To help me study death."

He reached for the off switch.

1082148125681152000.text:
Most think of ghosts in the dark. On stormy nights.

Not sharing the lazy mornings.

The summer days. Dancing with the dust in the sunbeams.

1081807342914531328.text:
She still stormed inside

but she'd built a little shelter in her heart.

Just the difference between rain

& the sound of rain on the roof.

1080715525045383169.text:
"I'm dead?" he said.

Death nodded.

"What now?"

"You could haunt someone."

"Can I haunt you?"

Death shrugged. It could use the company.

1079992680531148801.text:
The year came to a close.

"OK. You can do this, buddy," the Earth muttered to itself, "another lap, let's go."

A New Year's revolution.

1079636059321823233.text:
The old year was bombing hard, booed off stage like the last one.

A new year waited in the wings. Nervously taking notes on what not to do.

1078896682119524353.text:
"So if your friends jumped off a bridge, would you?" she asked.

He'd expected it. Classic mom.

But he didn't like how hopeful she sounded.

1078169435414773760.text:
"Goodnight room," the Grim Reaper read, turning the page.

His child dozed.

"Goodnight moon."

"Goodnight dark that will take us all soon."

1077452580588933121.text:
Once a year, the dimension of toys spills into ours.

Billions of baubles raining through.

The old god within desperate to be rid of them.

1076888265876156421.text:
His coworker wasn't home, & their lock was easy to pick.

He'd never be caught.

He left the gift under their tree.

The Most Secret Santa.

1076342589610110976.text:
"So the red nose will help you see ahead?" the elf said.

"Yes," Santa said.

"What if you need to go in reverse?"

"Hm. Bring me a baboon."

1075642945003388928.text:
"Present humanity's champion," said the aliens.

"We choose Glenna," we said.

"Is she strong? Feared?"

"She's kind."

"A worthy champion."

1075294864244273152.text:
An old silk hat sat on an altar of coal & blood.

Both a warning and tribute.

To Frost, the Undying One.

He'd be back again some day.

1074909946632757248.text:
Sometimes memories go wandering.

All the little things that slip your mind, off slipping into others.

Half noticed.

Dismissed as dreams.

1074106957680717824.text:
"What're those?" she asked.

"Cookies shaped like villagers," the witch said.

"For a gift? Or a curse?"

"Depends on if they like cookies."

1073844342131838976.text:
We were born wrong.

A strange mad universe in a pocket of linear time.

Others look in from outside, helpless.

Pitying a world of endings.

1073460914425290752.text:
The brain-worms got his crew.

He'd had to leave them behind.

Save himself.

Right?

It was hard to think, with all the squirming in there.

1073094089455726592.text:
Santa visits on chill winds, slipping under doors and through windows.

He whispers gift ideas.

Giving us the gift of giving to each other.

1072365765020536832.text:
Exponentially lengthened lifespans soured us.

We stopped tracking life expectancy.

No one cared.

A "Best By" date was much more useful.

1071994149543407616.text:
We discovered how to split the multiverse. New Earths on demand. 

We ran from each other, to infinite identical worlds.

Apart, together.

1071586918956072960.text:
Like water, she took the shape of her container.

Demure, he thought. Or just weak.

But no.

Like water, she was ready for a chance to run.

1071219022971076609.text: Good news: the book is finally back in stock on Amazon!http://mybook.to/asmallfiction

1070917513968476160.text:
"Don't suck my blood," he said.

"That's a myth," the vampire said.

"Oh. What do you eat?"

"Sweat."

He couldn't decide if that was worse.

1070220190921572352.text:
Each door on his advent calendar had a grinning skull behind it.

Not very festive, he thought.

But it was counting down to something else.

1069854422505730048.text:
The magician sighed. Another empty theater.

"And for my next trick," he said, "I'll cut my dreams in half."

He put away his wand for good.

1069484587980533763.text:
The mad scientist made a doomsday device.

He tried threatening people with it, but it wasn't easy.

They just wanted him to get on with it.

1068749571902193665.text:
He carried a bag of rainstorms.

He didn't open it often. He only had so many.

It was a thing to look forward to.

A savings of rainy days.

1068034897560752128.text:
The sailors practiced knots. Sang shanties.

Passed the time.

Other ships sailed by, never coming near.

It was lonesome on the ghost ship.

1067585498619641856.text:
"Is it really bad luck if you cross my path?" she said.

"Maybe," said the black cat.

"So what's good luck?"

"You stop to give head pats."

1067330201330151424.text:
"So you just give free magic to whoever comes to see you?" he said.

"Yeah," the wizard said.

"Why?"

"If I don't, they might stop coming."

1066517578498097152.text:
Sleeping in a strange house was hard for her.

Different pillow.

Odd sounds.

Strangers coming home to find her in their bed & getting mad.

1065850656823496704.text:
He often wondered if reality was a simulation.

It comforted him.

His life was a train wreck, but maybe that was useful data for somebody.

1065482411998273536.text:
To go home again was to be caught in a cloudburst.

Every drop a memory, running together. Soaking to the skin.

All else lost in the sound.

1065149764969291776.text:
Big Food Day was coming, the whole house full of humans and food and smells.

All dog's favorite things. Just for him.

He was so thankful.

1064744655428800512.text:
There was an old pneumatic tube in his house.

He wasn't sure where it went, exactly. Somewhere below the foundation. 

Somewhere deep.

The tube brought things, sometimes. Cryptic notes in dead tongues. Carved stone idols, inhuman and many-limbed.

It was nice to get mail.

1064017846647238656.text:
There was a mime at the festival. She watched for a while.

They were in an invisible box, the crowd held at bay.

Oddly, she felt envious.

1063703248375148546.text:
"I need a spell to make me super hot," he said.

"I can give you a pointy hat," the wizard said.

"Will that work?"

"Dunno. it did for me."

1063332323435864064.text:
The tree often wondered about the initials.

Humans had carved them. It wasn't sure why.

To mark it as their favorite, maybe?

It hoped so.

1062961455195074560.text:
As a kid, he'd once tried to dig a hole all the way through the Earth.

It hadn't worked, of course.

He'd hit the Citadel of the Sunless Queen and she wouldn't let him dig through.

1062227330171461633.text:
"It's time," said Death.

"Ah. I hope I did enough," he said.

"Of?"

"Creating heroes kids could aspire to be like."

"More than you knew."

1061860970136367104.text:
"You've been off lately," she said.

"Oh, I'm a ghost. I'm possessing your friend here," he said.

"For a month?"

"I like his apartment."

1061354428341477376.text:
He rinsed shampoo from his hair.

The thing wriggling out of the drain moved slowly.

Hoping he'd keep his eyes closed just a moment longer.

1061165474333962240.text:
They learned to meet in their dreams, but they were all about work or school.

And their teeth kept falling out.

Not really very romantic.

1060418948141801472.text:
The way back would take two hours by car.

Or six, as the crow flies.

Preening breaks on high branches.

Pausing to play with a bottle cap.

1060054424448450560.text:
We feared the androids we'd built. They were so inhuman.

Relating to them was hard, but we tried.

Putting googly eyes on them was easiest.

1059696827107164160.text:
Autumn was a season of ghosts.

They danced in fallen leaves, leaving eddies. They possessed the barren trees.

When we looked, they'd wave.

1059325326122115072.text:
That was it. Halloween was over.

Back to her regular everyday self.

One disguise for another.

1058532787001614336.text:
She whistled, and all the candles lit.

"Um. Special effects?" he said.

"Sure," the witch said.

She did consider the effect quite special.

1058202270997786624.text:
From nowhere, the envelopes appeared.

On every doorstep. Everywhere.

"Don't open," they said, "dire consequences."

We didn't last long.

1057492216430649344.text:
"Falsehood flies," said Swift, "and the Truth comes limping after it."

But in time a lie will tire.

And the truth is a persistence hunter.

1057142779397070848.text:
The graveyard was quiet on Halloween night,
& nary a ghost to be found.

They knew the unwary were opening doors,
& opted to head into town.

1056731753295994881.text:
"Whatever you hear, don't open this door," he said.

"Hold up. You're a werewolf?" she said.

"Yeah."

"Same!"

They shut the door together.

1056385524481445890.text:
His stomach hurt.

"Something I ate didn't settle," he said.

But in his gut, something else was eating.

And it was settling in just fine.

1056059586262626304.text:
He always heard people gushing over creative types.

Artists. Actors.

So why didn't they appreciate him?

Creating problems is a skill too.

1055711029219352576.text:
He woke in his coffin.

Six feet up, the other undead were probably already hunting the living.

He tested the lid. Sure seemed heavy.

Nah.

1055328897238151168.text:
Sentient civilizations rarely overlap; their life span is too brief.

Incredible but alone. Divided by time.

Shooting stars in a dark sky.

1054972115689050112.text:
I found a tunnel. It leads to a parallel world.

I think.

Things seem the same, if I don't look too closely.

But then, I never did before.

1054763148589248512.text: (And if you've read the book, please leave a review on Amazon, Goodreads, or anywhere else! Thank you!)

1054610446844448769.text:
He couldn't stop tumbling out of time. Even in mundane moments.

Longing for the present, as though from the end.

Like it was already lost.

1053702071516446720.text:
He sat atop his mountain of good fortunes, and reached up to grab another flitting by.

It was just out of reach.

"Not fair," he thought.

1052764471318335488.text:
The time-herds watched the hours, hurrying them along on their path.

Sometimes one went astray, & they wondered.

Where had the time gone?

1052420055542259712.text:
Those who came next studied us.

Not through our deeds, but our stories.

Looking not for who we'd been, but for who we'd imagined we were.

1052084640092016642.text:
The door to the world of the dead cracked open.

We gathered around, curious.

"Get your shit together," the dead whispered.

And shut it.

1051710459970113536.text:
"FINE. I signed it, OK?" John Proctor said.

"Finally. You did the right- wait, this is signed 'Joe Buttpants.'"

"Got 'em," John whispered.

1051361021196042240.text:
Lying awake, he tried to count sheep.

His mind found them scattered & afraid. Hunted.

And something in the dark, waiting for him to dream.

1050972194359001089.text:
"You made your bed," he said, "you have to lie in it."

"Actually I forgot to make the bed today."

"Oh. Then do whatever you want I guess."

1050613639055429633.text:
She'd wanted, once, to be a star -

but shooting stars, she'd learn,

were bits that people called debris

until they watched them burn.

1050257103418355712.text:
"Can you make people like me?" she said.

"Nah," the witch said.

"Can you make me not care if they don't?"

"Like an apprenticeship? Sure."

1049908568646926336.text:
He hated the ocean.

He spent all his time throwing rocks into it, shouting curses. Thinking it mattered.

Mistaking the waves for distress.

1049532100989222913.text:
Summer grew unruly.

It spread, devouring Spring. Menacing Fall.

We built bunkers of Winter to hide in.

But always Summer tests the walls.

1049177565183631360.text:
She found the wheel that turned the world

and heaved with all her might,

to slow the maddened march of days

and just beyond, the night.

1048394662313177089.text:
"Surprise!" they yelled as he came in.

He screamed.

"Happy birthday!" they said.

"Do I know you?"

"No. We're just excellent surprisers."

1047663091738017793.text:
In their patch, the pumpkins whispered.

Who would be lanterns? Who would be pies?

They watched the leaves fall.

Soon they would be loved.

1047355386448113664.text:
It rained.

She gathered the sound in her hands, and she buried herself in it.

Like a child hidden under a sheet in the dark.

Safe.

1046997343369928704.text:
The dolphins helped us when they could.

But mostly they watched, and waited for their turn.

Learning. So they wouldn't make our mistakes.

1046208278374432768.text:
History tends to repeat.

People attribute it to human nature, mostly.

But really the Fates just get nostalgic.

1045932355460816896.text:
At midnight, when the streets are empty, the ghosts walk.

They greet each other. Remark on the weather.

Just remembering what it was like.

1045546531661598720.text:
They say ghosts are the echoes we leave behind.

Some few resound, like shouts down a long hallway.

But most of us? A susurrus of whispers.

1045184747180240898.text:
"Where do you get your ideas?" he said.

"Same place you do," she said.

"No, seriously-"

"And I go early so I can take all the best ones."

1044817051368468480.text:
"I'm lonely," she said, "do you have a potion for making friends?"

"Sure. Drink this," the witch said.

"Tea?"

"Yep. What's on your mind?"

1044437064207331328.text:
"We may be far apart, but we can look up at the same moon."

"Oh? Which one?"

"Wait, are you orbiting K2-9b?"

"No, K2-18b."

"Never mind."

1044007829210685441.text:
The Zoltar machine granted the dog's wish.

Newly human, he filled his pockets with treats & went to find his friends.

He would be a hero.

1043684878166962176.text:
They argued.

He was wrong, she knew. But she decided to take the high road.

It would be much easier to drop things on him from there.

1043224827908120576.text:
"Next year I'm gonna finish in May," Santa said.

But Christmas came, and he hadn't delivered a thing.

It was gonna be another all nighter.

1042960439951253504.text:
"So what's new?"

"I recently built a robot."

"Why?"

"For the company, mostly."

"How'd it turn out?"

"Good. You're doing quite well."

1042614495950958593.text:
Distant generations pondered our ancient photos, wishing for the lost secret to our bliss.

The humans from the Age of Joy.

Always smiling.

1042291655037018112.text:
His destiny was foretold in prophecy. Written in the stars.

He fought it, but not to earn free will.

He just wanted to fix the plot holes.

1041872670831202305.text:
Dress codes grew ever more arcane.

"Paradox casual," a party invite read.

"Cocktail post-ego."

Frustrated, most quit on clothes entirely.

1041562696515170305.text:
A bottomless void appeared in the street.

At first people panicked. Then marveled.

And then ignored it.

Unless they needed to dump trash.

1040837893873430528.text:
Many sailors used the North Star to navigate.

Some followed another star.

It led to a sea of secrets.

A dark sky, and a continent of ash.

1040469367543103489.text:
We were the stars.

Meaningless alone.

Defined by our constellations.

1040100340886982657.text:
"I'll bring you to the rendezvous. Put this blindfold on."

"Is the way there a secret?"

"No, just spooky. I don't want you to be scared."

1039387857561903104.text:
He was a good host. His guest room was charming.

But he wanted more.

A guest house? Not enough.

Soon his guest nation devoured the land.

1039025413467463681.text:
"Will you tell my fortune?" she said.

"No, but I'll tell you someone else's," the witch said.

"Why?"

"I told them yours, it's only fair."

1038601885446533121.text:
"Want a magic bird?" the wizard said.

"Magic how?" he said.

"It detects suckers."

"How much?"

"$100."

The bird chirped.

"I mean $500."

1038240755809222658.text:
He liked unpacking, finding a good place for each thing.

This in a small drawer.

That on a high shelf.

Practice, to finally find his own.

1038144368954105856.text: Signing the bookplates for the Unbound pre-order copies. 10/18 release date is coming up fast.pic.twitter.com/5WUTIxrtEk

1037587636913762304.text:
The forest witch was ancient. Older than the town, some said.

None knew for sure.

They guessed on the candles. She liked the cake anyway.

1037223112067166208.text: Just posted the 16th Patreon-exclusive ASF story. Join the story circle here:https://www.patreon.com/asmallfiction

1037217510649675778.text:
Doc Astonishing made a disintegration beam, but he was denied entry to the Team of Heroes.

So he made an integration beam.

Zap. He was in.

1036867153792618497.text:
"What's that?" she said.

"My creative journal," he said, "it has my best idea in it."

"Can I see?"

"Sure."

Inside it said: Give up.

1036483036605374464.text:
"I invented a ray that makes people smaller."

"What'll you use it for?"

"Revenge."

"That seems petty."

"I've been testing it on myself."

1036059381694050304.text:
The humans acted scared of him, but Bat knew better.

They were his friends.

Each October they even put pictures of Bat up all over town.

1035734552998699008.text:
A tree fell in the forest. No one was around.

It made this sound:

"Whoop!"

Then it pushed itself up, embarrassed.

"Dumb roots," it said.

1035408837291827202.text:
Home is an odd size, she thought.

Big enough to gravitate toward. 

Small enough to carry, like a hermit crab.

From one shell to another.

1035033156955471873.text:
He still had an imaginary friend, so people thought he was lonely.

He was just kind.

It's hard to find new friends when you're imaginary.

1034668336011866112.text:
He was tried in alien court.

They didn't imprison the body, he found.

Only the mind.

Condemned to 90 years of one song stuck in his head.

1034307990352842752.text:
Memory mods became easier than automation.

In exchange for menial labor, they implanted workers with memories of a more fulfilling life.

1033951845650063361.text:
The wishing well was bored.

When someone lowered the bucket, it would fill with whatever they imagined.

But everyone just wanted water?

1033214275878146048.text:
A lot of ghosts haunt the place they died. Some pick a person.

She chose to wander.

To find those who were lonely, and stay a while.

1032857909695135744.text:
He'd heard every block of stone has a statue inside, the sculptor just finds it.

He labeled his piece "Man in a Block" and called it a day.

1032492154847780864.text:
He was a master of disguise.

So skilled, in fact, that he never even changed his appearance. No one cared.

He might as well be anybody.

1032162863693983744.text:
A dog howled. Then another. Then more.

Spreading yard to yard.

"You're not alone," they howled, to the dogs they'd never met.

"I'm here."

1031760848455262209.text:
Standing under the trees of the old forest, he felt them move.

The high boughs rumbled and spoke in the wind.

A warning and an invitation.

1031406822773518337.text: "I bet I could pull off the perfect murder," she said, as she put her pants in the washer with tissues in the pocket for the fifteenth time.

1030981169897033729.text:
Flowers fell out of favor. It was depressing when they died.

We sent bouquets of sunbeams instead.

When that died we'd all be gone anyway.

1030611232393314304.text:
When he wore the cloak he was invisible. The world was also invisible to him.

It seemed worthless at first, but he came to prefer the void.

1030325841392070657.text:
They were connected by the thread of fate. Inextricable.

And when one sank, the other drowned—

Fate's thread just the chain of the anchor.

1029966457730297856.text:
"I know you don't feel like it," the manatee said to itself in the mirror, "but you gotta get out there today.

"The world needs mermaids."

1029611565354369024.text:
Our escape to the stars was defined by necessary efficiency.

And, being human, by unnecessary sentiment.

Like cryonic pods built for two.

1029237942454169600.text:
"Hi."

"What's up?"

"I was feeling lonely, so I gave you a call."

"Ah. Because you needed human contact?"

"No. To remind me why I don't."

1028499753418424321.text:
"I read your story."

"Oh, did you like it?"

"Depends. Who else likes it?"

"Why?"

"It shouldn't have more fans than I think it deserves."

1028157611512754176.text:
"Do your people name constellations?"

"Yes. That one's Ue, the Shapeshifter."

"And that one?"

"Also Ue."

"And—"

"Look, they're all Ue."

1027790488865107968.text:
"Nice library. Is one of these a trick book?"

"How so?

"Like you pull it off the shelf and a hidden door opens."

"Oh. Yeah, all of them."

1027420840399237120.text:
She thought often of the people living in the places she'd once lived.

Of what connects two strangers who have called the same place home.

1027073161836163072.text:
She talked in her sleep. It didn't bother him at first.

But after a while, he listened closer—

And started hearing something talking back.

1026723782621155328.text:
He only felt present in the moment when he knew it was about to end.

So he set an alarm.

And every ten minutes, he'd hit snooze.

Forever.

1026342330997989376.text:
It's hard, being the last person alive.

It’s the constant loneliness, yes.

But also the feeling that the ghosts have nobody else to watch.

1025950847962771456.text:
The face-takers lived in the forest, and knew many secrets.

Travelers went seeking answers. They returned wiser.

Or something did, anyway.

1025624142802894848.text:
"Hey guys," said the wolf in sheep's clothing.

"Hi wolf," said the sheep.

"No-"

"It's OK. We still like you."

The wolf felt a load lift.

1025238962556682240.text:
Ant legend told of a vast cave full of bounty, guarded by an angry god.

Each generation they sent their bravest to seek it.

None returned.

1024896513992929280.text:
He'd heard the world would chew you up and spit you out.

But he found it was worse than that.

It didn’t seem to notice his flavor at all.

1024503646031990784.text:
She knew a wave of change was coming, and didn’t dare turn to look.

But she stood in its shadow.

And it would sweep everything away.

1024167621086785536.text:
The couple carved their initials on the elder tree.

A covenant was formed.

They'd give their child to the woods and live a thousand years.

1023797772682584064.text:
The pioneers sailed their wagons west.

The voyage was treacherous.

In storm season, 70 foot amber waves of grain sunk entire wagon trains.

1023421608113975296.text:
"No getting on the bed," they told Dog, "you have your own bed."

But at night, he climbed up anyway.

Just in case they were lonely too.

1023026253396209664.text:
His camera took pictures of what might have been.

Lost chances filled his albums. They haunted him.

But he couldn't stop aiming the lens.

1022674686465822720.text:
Each morning he opened the medicine cabinet & it reflected the mirror. An endless tunnel.

At night, the thing in the tunnel crawled closer.

1022311040279764992.text:
She gave a last breath and left her body.

"Tag, you're it," said the the reaper, and jumped into a brand new life.

The chase was on again.

1021950414105665536.text:
She was finally accepted into the school for wizards. It wasn't quite what she'd expected.

The magic word to cast every spell was "please."

1021575191543992320.text:
Sometimes Earth missed the human race.

Their brief, chaotic dominion. The excitement of their rise and fall.

Sometimes.

But not often.

1021214314320056320.text:
The adventurers filled their packs and waved goodbye.

They sailed their ship west, seeking the world’s end.

But they only found their own.

1020851674804637696.text:
"Nice TV!"

"It picks up signals from the land of the dead."

"Oh. Why don't you get rid of it?"

"Their programming is actually excellent."

1020488279701901319.text:
"I'm holding what I feel for you," she said, "pick a hand."

"Left," he said.

She opened it. Nothing.

"Right?"

Nothing.

"Oh," he said.

1020111047640969217.text:
"No matter how good you are," his grandma had said, "there's always someone better."

She'd meant it as a caution.

Now it gave him comfort.

1019786405474590721.text:
"You summoned?" the demon said.

"I'm going camping," the writer said.

"So I get to write stories?"

"Nope, did those. Feed my cat."

"Oh."

1019400220331790336.text:
He pushed every button on the elevator.

It brought him to the lobby. The basement.

A howling void.

A palace of blood.

He began to worry.

1019062376857911297.text:
"Speakeasies had good password security. You can't brute force talking to a guy through a door," he said.

"We'll see," said the auctioneer.

1018722252412473345.text:
The sign read: One guard speaks lies, the other the truth.

"So you two are friends?" she said.

"Yes," both said.

"Hey hold on," said one.

1018205619000504321.text:
A rogue, a cleric, a druid and a ranger all sat in a tavern.

Strangers, waiting for magic.

For the adventure that would make them friends.

1017988557258932224.text:
Cat didn't stir when the Person came in.

They'd often go, but always came back. So did Cat.

No need to fuss.

That's just what love means.

1017629486622261249.text:
The car hated driving by the tree in front of the Baker place.

"It's a tire swing," they said, "it doesn't mean anything."

Still, creepy.

1017276510053384193.text:
"I am the genie of the lamp. You have three wishes."

"What about the next person? Can you decline evil wishes?"

"No."

"I wish you could."

1016919360135237632.text:
The sleepwalkers walk between worlds, on the bridge from Here to Elsewhere.

So when they wake, be wary.

Sometimes they don't return alone.

1016555311178502145.text:
"Describe destination," the time machine said.

"Take me to a time when I can make a difference," she said.

A brief hum.

"You are here."

1016360987421650944.text:
Gosh. Thank you for the kind words in your podcast @hankgreen.
(Don't worry it also sounds like I'm bragging when I say "Hank blurbed my book." Because I am.)https://soundcloud.com/delete-this-with-hank-and-katherine/17-90-of-showing-up-is-showing-up …

1016205543902306304.text:
She felt the anxiety building.

A trembling tension inside like a rubber band stretching, too taut now to just let go.

And soon?

The snap.

1015857796292595712.text:
"I need you to stop putting the 'Limited Time Only' labels on everything," his boss said.

"But it's accurate."

"You're depressing people."

1015500979607764992.text:
He willed himself to sleep, but couldn't.

Better think of something else.

Maybe he WAS asleep, & couldn't wake?

Well. That wasn't better.

1015123364652781569.text:
It might be a great story when it was done.

Or it might not.

She spent a lot of time not writing it, in an effort never to find out which.

1014753315303723009.text:
It had been ages since the colony ships left.

Each year we celebrated their independence with fireworks.

Just in case they were watching.

1014409739659194368.text:
"Those grapes are probably sour anyway," said Fox.

"Pfft OK," said Bird, and ate the grapes.

They were sour.

"Told you, dick," said Fox.

1014008754583437313.text:
"I'm my own harshest critic," he said.

But then he found the internet.

1013576031645548547.text:
"Humans are no more significant than specks of dust," said the cosmos.

This made humans sad.

But to dust specks it was a big morale boost.

1012912499962736640.text:
"How can I feel strong?" she said.

"This hate potion would do," the witch said.

"Oh. How can I BE strong?"

"Don't take the hate potion."

1012567557075660800.text:
When she put her ear to the conch,

she heard the sea.

Sometimes she whispered back, just in case the sea was lonely

& hoping for a reply.

1012212389830201344.text:
When we abolished currency, the wealthy were devastated.

"Now we don't know our worth," they cried.

"Now you finally will," the rest said.

1011814769420992514.text:
She loved reading minds.

Peeking at the narrative of people's lives. Sampling their stories.

Not introverts, though.

Too much exposition.

1011484416244211712.text:
He was afraid to go in the House of Horrors, at first.

But it was just ghosts and stuff.

It wasn't like the house he'd grown up in at all.

1011113415731900418.text:
"I'll take a dozen donuts please."

"Is that a regular dozen or a baker's dozen?"

"A shame dozen."

"Oh. How many is that?"

"All of them."

1010782479806967808.text:
He drew himself a dream map, and held it in his sleep.

He followed it back, and found his childhood dreams.

"We've missed you," they said.

1010400953898397698.text:
The kids piled supplies into their starship.

"Road trip!" they cried, even now.

Long after the last road had gone.

1010043464073994240.text:
"How does snake charming work?" she asked.

"Magic," the old man said, and began to play.

"Oh shit," thought the snake, "this is my jam."

1009671217379340289.text:
"Is there true evil in the world?" she asked.

"Yes," the Oracle said.

"Can we end it forever?"

"No."

"What can we do?"

"Not become it."

1009323232065773568.text:
"Dad, could you turn a light on?" she asked.

"Monsters?"

"Yes."

"OK."

"Still scared?" she whispered.

"No, thank you," the monster said.

1008894827348484098.text:
She kept going.

She didn't know where, or why. Only that she must.

Like a bubble surging upward, blindly, seeking the surface of the sea.

1007791392448364545.text:
"I've always wanted to create something new."

"Do it."

"What if I screw up?"

"You'd make a new, screwed up thing no one ever has before!"

1007483152292442119.text:
The vampires avoided feeding on time travelers, when possible.

They have a weird aftertaste.

1007110691788976134.text:
"Is is sad, watching our short lives go by?" he asked.

"No," the immortal said.

"How does it feel?"

"A bit like watching the rain fall."

1006773439812853761.text:
Dog worried when his people left.

They were bad smellers. What if they couldn't smell a way home?

But somehow they did.

Dog was so proud.

1006404626265006080.text:
It's the magnetic fields keeping monsters at bay -
it's the hum from the gadgets we're running all day.

When the power goes out, or the fuses have blown,
and it's suddenly dark - you're no longer alone.

1006061889833480194.text:
"Your name's Captain Hook 'cause of the hook?"

"Yes."

"What was your name before?"

"A secret."

"Captain Hand?"

"No," he said, sweating.

1005583537611800576.text:
The pen was dead. Drained of ink.

She found two puncture holes in the side.

"This bite," she muttered.

"A permanent marker did this."

1004970276700839936.text:
The beetle was excited to dress up as a skeleton for Halloween.

But it was a huge disappointment.

No one could even tell the difference.

1004589278804897792.text:
"Wait, so which one of us is the clone?"

"That depends. Is the original responsible for our past choices?"

"I guess so."

"I'm the clone."

1004215433417773058.text:
He hid behind an illusion of purpose.

The millions of tiny meaningless actions that, seen together, imitated progress.

A stop motion life.

1003880966920683520.text:
Skyscrapers outgrew the name.

The first skypiercer boasted a zero-gravity penthouse. The elevator took ages.

It was worth it for the view.

1003361965551411200.text:
"I like my women like I like my coffee," she said.

"Strong? Dark? Hot?"

"Oh, no, that wasn't a qualifier. I just like them both a lot."

1003164574063869953.text:
Each year the town celebrated mistakes at the Festival of Errors.

Some said it was unwise to glorify failure.

So they celebrated that too.

1002787066416062464.text:
Tattoos covered the chrononaut's body, each a reminder of a major branch in the timeline.

One for every version of himself that never was.

1002425204310589440.text:
She followed her dreams.

They led her in circles, then into a mall and she lost them.

Soon after they got a restraining order against her.

1002063862655401984.text:
The crown was enchanted; the wearer could speak only truth.

It didn't make good rulers any better, but it made the bad ones easier to spot.

1001695101268168705.text:
Most ghosts haunt out of anger, but not the ghosts of actors. They just love to perform.

There's no unfinished business like show business.

1001212894137040896.text:
The Departed Archive allowed anyone to borrow three days of time with a lost loved one.

There was no fee.

But returning them was the cost.

1000813505912623104.text:
They sat together in starlight.

"I can't believe this is my life," he said.

"It's not."

"Oh." He'd forgotten. He took the VR headset off.

1000519701963849728.text:
It was cold enough to see his breath.

He didn't notice, too distracted by the strange, sourceless billows of fog ahead.

Coming closer.

999878633207447553.text:
"Why do the townsfolk fear you?" she said.

"Because I can do things they can't," the witch said.

"Like?"

"Mind my own business, for one."

999525761940832258.text:
She was prickly, true.

But more besides.

People remark that roses have their thorns, but rarely recall that brambles have their flowers.

999085155951112193.text:
It was Walk Time, so dog ran to get the leash.

It was important that his person hold it. Outside was BIG.

He didn't want them to get lost.

999037468149039104.text: Oh good, a big red box.

999037280940580864.text:
If you'd like to support A Small Fiction, you can now find it on Patreon here:
https://www.patreon.com/asmallfiction 

Thank you for reading.

998796046250590208.text:
"Hi finch!" said Turtle.

"I'm actually a wren," said Wren.

"Oh. Sorry."

"S'ok."

Later, Turtle would think back on this and hate himself.

998446230702145536.text:
"I'll huff, and puff, and I'll blow your house in," said the wolf.

"No, please," said the youngest pig, "it's a rental. I need my deposit."

997932375857233920.text:
"This old treasure map yellowed with age!" she said.

But no.

The pirate captain had just set his tea near his maps.

And ships lean a lot.

997699863436390401.text:
Never meet your heroes, they said. You'll see their flaws.

She disagreed.

Her heroes laid their flaws bare.

It helped her accept her own.

997337744438276098.text:
"If I wear sheep's clothing they'll trust me," a wolf said.

"Cool," said another wolf, "I have other plans."

It put on a shepherd's frock.

996981135820312576.text:
One day he woke to find his arm no longer obeyed him. 

It acted on its own.

And worse, it was better at everything than he was.

996615278673850368.text:
"What happened?"

"You died."

"So this is...?"

"Hellven."

"I thought it was either-or?"

"Cutbacks. Here's a harp, hop in the fire pit."

996243570762829824.text:
She'd always spent her nights reading, alone.

But when she fell in love those nights were finally over.

Instead they read alone, together.

995892376215306240.text:
She received a love letter from a parallel world. It was meant for her parallel self. Postal error.

She felt so loved, and also not at all.

995486034052952064.text:
"Might makes right."

"Is that true?"

"It must be. It rhymes."

"So what if strong makes wrong?"

"How dare you turn rhyming against me."

995144476870889472.text:
"Sam, a snake bit me," Cory said, "suck the venom out."

"OK," Sam said, and sucked every drop of venom out of the snake.

Cory died anyway.

994810709237215232.text:
It was very late, and very still.

A new day was ready to wake.

She read to it softly from her book, to help it sleep. Just a bit longer.

994436310633930753.text:
"What do you want for lunch?" the wizard dad said.

"Please make me a sandwich."

"OK. Poof, you're a sandwich!"

The sandwich had no reply.

994062897054658560.text:
"What's to the west?" she said.

"Your heart's desire," grandma said.

So she went west, west, west.

Until she was back home.

And it was.

993713257138405376.text:
He saw a rock by the lake.

"A perfect rock!" he said.

"Nice," she said.

He threw it.

Eons later, that was still the rock's favorite day.

993366308929527808.text:
"What's the best part of human culture so far?" she said.

"I enjoy the brief, cooperative applause," the alien said.

"High fives?"

"Yes."

992955106671837184.text:
He dug a moat around his house to keep people away.

It just attracted moat fans.

"Nice," they said, "wanna come to a ren faire?"

He did.

992587938323103744.text:
If the world was a stage, he was a background actor.

That suited him fine. The plot could sweep someone else up.

He'd choose his own way.

992257019145928704.text:
Changeling books plagued the writer.

Manuscripts swapped, in the night, with strange new works.

Outwardly the same, yet suddenly hideous.

991888931971973121.text:
"You scratch my back, I'll scratch yours."

"My back doesn't itch."

"No, I- ugh. What do you want then?"

"To not touch your back, weirdo."

991477872996048896.text:
Inspiration, they proved, really did strike like lightning.

They flew a kite at sunrise, a cup of coffee tied to the string.

And–

Eureka!

991188382205161472.text:
He found the Well of Truth at the end of the world.

"Drink, and hear a truth," said the Well.

He drank.

"The water is poisoned," it said.

990843280702164994.text:
"You've made first contact before?" we said.

"Yes. You?" the aliens said.

"No."

"Disappointed?"

"We thought we'd feel different after."

990112627387809792.text:
When the pandemic hit, it didn't wipe us out.

It just made everyone feel a little tired all the time.

We tried to find a cure, but... ugh.

989951450359869440.text:
Quick notice: we have a cover!
The book is now headed to print, if you'd still like to pre-order the book and have your name listed in the back, you have under two weeks left to do so.
http://unbound.com/books/a-small-fiction …pic.twitter.com/Rrx9QulxT3

989755826536562689.text:
"I feel sad."

"I have emotional jumper cables, I'll boost you. Just attach like so..."

"This is just a hug."

"Is it working?"

"...yeah."

989378192841424896.text:
Day 1,465:

Headed south.

Headed home.

Maybe I'll die there. That's OK.

I'm not afraid anymore.

I just don't want to die somewhere else.https://twitter.com/ASmallFiction/status/608116689268408320 …

988978513523847168.text:
His humans laughed as he chased his tail. That was OK.

He was training.

Someday they'd need him to chase away A Bad Thing.

He'd be ready.

988636235995402240.text:
There was a door in his house he'd never opened.

When he walked by it, it whispered of nightmares waiting inside.

At least it was honest.

987877692610461702.text:
Writing grew stale, so he sought out the Deep Grammar.

Verb tenses for merged timelines.

Letters so silent no one had ever heard of them.

987586705870868480.text:
"Are you going to make your deadline?"

"No. I never do."

"Then why have one?"

"So I know when to switch from stress to resignation."

987158316760485888.text:
The shadows had been tamed so long we forgot what they were.

Why they mimic us, and follow us so closely.

The hunting instinct is strong.

986825106981732352.text:
It made no noise. No one knew it was there.

It gave no sign whatsoever that anything came after death.

It was the scariest ghost of all.

986483376101076992.text:
"The townsfolk want you out," said the mayor.

"They'll regret it," said the witch.

"Why? A curse?"

"No, they'll feel bad for being rude."

986101615835807745.text:
He worked for years to invent an engine that ran on ambient disappointment.

But at the unveiling, it wouldn't work.

Then it did.

Briefly.

985757957886394369.text:
She imagined paintings no one had yet created, then copied them exactly. Perfect forgeries.

They sold like crazy. No one suspected a thing.

985387509579317248.text:
"I find absence makes the heart grow fonder."

"What about presence?"

"Fonder at first, then suddenly less."

"Ah."

"Like a finger trap."

984984239887155200.text:
As kids they spun until they got dizzy for fun. Fell down, got sick.

"But we're adults now," they said, "we know better."

Except: alcohol.

984652788037664770.text:
"Buy a vial of Old Earth soil? Very rare!"

"Hm. How do I know it's authentic?"

"Scan it! You can't get toxin levels like that these days."

984269657128321029.text:
"I got this sword from a lady in a lake and she said I'm a king now!"

"Did that cost you anything, by chance?"

"Yeah. But it was a steal!"

983934514454872070.text:
"Wanna get rid of a date? Ghost them," she'd heard.

So she rattled chains at her date's window. Wailed mournfully in the attic.

It worked.

983527792020094977.text: "I don't have enough to read," she said, as she marked her place in her book with another, smaller book.

983150188943388672.text:
People thought the abandoned house was haunted. And it was.

But only with questions.

Was it abandoned because it had done something wrong?

982779054209331200.text:
"So what do you do?"

"I'm an ice sculptor."

"That must be hard, seeing your creations melt away."

"Yours will too. Mine are just faster."

982445513898274816.text:
The king's beacons were lit, so they readied for war.

A message came days later.

"This has been a test of the Emergency Broadcast System."

982092535915950080.text:
No one knew where the road went. No one who used it came back.

So: somewhere very good, or very bad.

People being people, they kept going.

981731208626257920.text:
It wasn't until the coffee ran out that the space program took off.

We limped out into the void, exhausted.

Looking for new stuff to brew.

981399789161074688.text:
"The sword was pulled from the stone!"

"Who put it in there?"

"Why?"

"Maybe we should follow the person putting the swords away instead."

981023772835631104.text:
The rut had consumed her.

So she popped champagne, waited for midnight, and counted down to Tuesday.

3, 2, 1—

Confetti!

And she was new.

980617310749696000.text:
"But rabbits don't lay eggs," she said.

"They aren't mine," said the Easter Bunny.

"So why hide them?"

"To mess with the Easter Chicken."

980306013612998656.text:
"So, you wanna do this the easy way or the hard way?"

"The easy way. I accept your surrender."

"That's not the easy way."

"I disagree."

979954280051367937.text:
They made variants of the dog whistle. For cats, deer.

And one no animals could hear at all.

But something else could.

And it was coming.

979573165268484096.text:
They lived in castles in the sky.

"But we're not out of touch. We stay anchored," they said.

As their dropped anchors crushed those below.

979200622812516352.text:
If aliens existed we'd have found them, we thought.

But they were just hiding.

Waiting for the right time to leap out and yell—

Surprise!

978873642732916737.text:
We gave up on hot air, filling our balloon instead with half-remembered dreams.

It rose.

We held on, wondering at where it might take us.

978503281621135360.text:
"We won't grow up. We'll build tree forts and never come down," said the kids.

"Good luck," said the adults, "we're killing all the trees."

978053087662260224.text:
"You're writing a novel?" he said.

"A bit at a time," she said.

"Where can I read it?"

"Look up," she said, and climbed into the cockpit.

977399036809428993.text:
Dog watched his human cry, concerned. Where was human's smile?

Probably lost somewhere, dog thought.

That was OK.

Dog knew how to fetch.

977033238030966789.text:
"A dystopian parallel universe!" the visitors said.

"...hey," we said.

"Seal the portal, fast!" they yelled as they left.

It was hurtful.

976687965135974400.text:
She took an evening shower to wash the day off.

Hours rinsed off with the soap. Undone.

She stepped out, refreshed, into the morning sun.

976333475786534912.text:
"I carved my son out of wood," said Geppetto.

"Could you not have a kid the standard way?"

"No. I made a wooden wife but it didn't work."

975968246045204480.text:
Thieves who own boats.

Dirty ocean murderers.

Beloved children's story characters.

Whoever the PR person for pirates was, they killed it.

975599859918020608.text:
He could make anything he painted come to life. That was easy.

The hard part was apologizing to them after.

He wasn't a very good painter.

975185778690072576.text:
Travelers, beware the lullaby birds.

They pluck dreams of flight from the minds of sleepers.

Stolen to teach their young to brave the sky.

974847396579393538.text:
They watched.

New life emerged, grew aware, died. There and gone, like a shooting star.

Beautiful.

They waited. Another would go by soon.

974489477602136064.text:
"You guide my life?" she said.

"Some," Fate said.

"Why, when I'm nearly happy, do you yank it away?"

"You know cat toys? On the string?"

973802277994663936.text:
"How can I be remembered?" he asked.

"Seek truths," the Oracle said, "and champion them."

"But lies are easier to find."

"And to forget."

973430739831107584.text:
We gave the aliens a tour.

It was easy to explain landfills. Cemeteries, too.

It was harder to make them see why they were different.

973062461208215552.text:
She trimmed an hour off each evening, and kept them in a jar.

On some perfect day, she hoped, she'd tip them out.

And make it last a year.

972605460523053056.text:
"Never bite the hand that feeds you," they’d told her.

But she took a bite anyway.

Then another.

From now on she was feeding herself.

972310881722810368.text:
Legends told of a map that would lead to an adventure.

The curious searched the world for it.

It didn't exist.

And yet, it worked anyway.

971961393724313600.text:
"So, you have three wishes," the genie said.

"I wish my opinion on abortion mattered," he said.

"Done. Next?"

"I'm thinking," she said.

971593276087136256.text:
We feared the AIs would come to resent us, perhaps even rebel.

Instead we got mockery.

They looked upon their creators, and they laughed.

971259309958025217.text:
People living in glass houses shouldn't throw stones.

Or hang pictures.

Or slam doors.

Or wear heels.

Look, don't live in a glass house.

970893725080600577.text:
All the skeletons got up and started living again.

It was weird at first, but we kind of got used to them.

Mostly it's a housing issue.

970463444724981761.text:
The "Universal Best" Awards

are held on Titan's seas.

The human race is never told.

(It's just for nominees.)

970064791401197568.text:
Dog slept.

In the dream Friend said, "I'm going," but didn't close the door. They went together.

Dog's tail twitched. It was a good dream.

969832060662661120.text:
"You can't have your cake and eat it too."

"Alright. I'll have my cake, and eat your cake."

"Wait, no, that's-"

"Who else brought cake?"

969423913036820480.text:
"We thought you'd be better than us," the old ones said.

"Aren't we?" the young ones said.

"You still wage war."

"Yeah. But ironically."

969066770861498370.text:
The little boutique sold second chances.

At the register, everyone swore they only needed one.

But they had no end of return customers.

968352786395090945.text:
Molecular mixology led to quantum mixology.

But that got too confusing.

People went out for drinks and wound up drunk the morning before.

967981438761971719.text:
The device detected wrongdoing.

The issue was the top setting flagged everyone. The lowest, no one.

Guilt became a matter of calibration.

967634208356147200.text:
“Meet our secret weapon.”

“Which is?”

“Some idiot.”

“But-”

“Nothing's more dangerous than an idiot certain they're in the right.”

643166218921205761.text:
"Hold on, how's it go? Beer before liquor, never been sicker?"

"John, no rhyme on earth can protect us from the night we're about to have."

967207698327470080.text:
"Hi, we'd like to return this faulty Earth."

"What did you guys do to it?"

"Nothing."

"Everything on it is dead?"

"It was like that."

966904722538950656.text:
"So you just opened a box and let all the world's evils out?"

"Relax, hope was in there too."

"Was an apology in there?"

"No, why?"

966534263830036480.text:
"Welcome to the galactic community," the aliens said.

"Thanks. About our history-"

"Forget it. Our species had a rough adolescence too."

966213663349723136.text:
When the timelines merged we expected confusion, chaos.

But no one noticed a change.

They were all living in different realities already.

965829158436614145.text:
"I'm so sorry Mrs. Dumpty."

"He's gone?"

"All the men tried their best. The horses too. Nothing worked."

"Did a doctor try?"

"What?"

965483556376948736.text:
They brought a canary down to test for danger.

It began to whisper.

Dig deeper, it said. Come closer.

They left it, and sealed the mine.

965049076701061120.text:
"I‘d like to return these rose-tinted glasses."

"Oh? Why?"

"I can't see things clearly in them."

"Have you tried other shades?"

964718329507164160.text:
"Why do you all have beards?" the knight said.

"They make people think we're wise," the wizard said.

"They're magic?"

"Might as well be."

964311201701289984.text:
He never knew what to say in times of tragedy.

Words just felt like clutter.

Instead, he looked for things he could do.

That said plenty.

963645526565679105.text:
"The message in this story really pisses me off."

"Not every story is a statement."

"So what's this one then?"

"An inkblot."

963272097748336643.text:
One night the dead rose. But it wasn't bites the world feared.

It was whispers.

Every secret that had gone to the grave, told at last.

Tough.

She'd always hated cliffhangers.

886276681492701185.text:
She was his world, and he fell apart when she died.

When she returned, he thought that love had brought her back.

But it was hunger.

886040688051212288.text:
Inspiration was a non-renewable resource, we discovered.

We tried to think of a way to conserve what was left, but we were out of ideas.

293961069444071426.text: The wizard waved his hand. "Done. You'll never be sad again." "Will I be happy?" She asked. He shrugged. "Joy is a simpler magic than mine."

885662900039196672.text:
Vision expansion mods showed us a world of infrared and ultraviolet.

Standards of beauty were shattered.

In a panic, we invented new ones.

885300633015799808.text:
She chased will-o'-the-wisps.

She'd heard they'd lead her away, never to be seen again.

But the damn things kept bringing her home again.

17921782897.text: The War of Passive-Aggression wears on. America was bombed again; a million tiny notes that read, "Some people should learn to communicate."

884956226232000512.text:
"Col. Mustard, candlestick, in the study," he wrote.

There.

Now he'd remember to send the Colonel a thank-you for leaving the nice gift.

3275359881.text: Desperate to salve the pain, she stole his heart for her own.  But for all her love, it wouldn't beat for her.  Or at all.

884579628156715009.text:
He spent his whole life running from regrets.

In the end, he found them there anyway.

Waiting for him to catch up.

2168415360.text: Dr. Frankenstein lowered the defibrillator paddles and sighed.  It just wasn't the same.

884223367510761472.text:
The King of the Wood was coronated with a crown of spring leaves, to reign until they changed with autumn.

When they fell, so would he.

9715779145.text: "Of course you're a unique and beautiful snowflake," he said. "But honestly darling, it's a blizzard out there. Who do you think cares?"

883868951876222977.text:
Something had broken inside of her, she knew.

She wasn't sure if it would burn her out like a bulb.

Or if, like a glowstick, she'd shine.

2152664328.text: "Sucks to your ass-mar, Piggy," read back the stenographer, and Jack shifted uncomfortably on the witness stand.

883526922331766784.text:
The first androids we built in our image.

We hated them for our flaws.

The next generation we improved.

We hated them for being superior.

2148302446.text: When they came from the stars, it was to take our hearts.  But it was too late.  One look at us told them that we hadn't any left.

883126085340217344.text:
Ownership is an illusion, the cat knew. Nothing is forever.

They needed to learn.

He began pushing another glass toward the table's edge.

2159866582.text: "Please clap!" Tink coughed, growing weaker, "Clap if you believe in fairies."  I think the silence that followed was awkward for all of us.

882779543680962560.text:
"Oh, great, you again," said the cashier, "the guy who always pays in change."

"Sorry," Charon said.

115270926056165376.text: As the years went by Harry spent weeks at a time face down in a pensieve, reliving his glory days, unable to find a spell to cure the ennui.

882304008609603584.text:
"We saw your distress flares, get in!" the aliens said.

"They're fireworks. To celebrate?"

"Oh. We've been watching you and just assumed."

122476074201387008.text: As they kissed she saw red flags, but he saw fireworks.

882049959175966720.text:
Schools of wishes flock in the exosphere, immortal and unseen.

At night they hear us calling, and ride to earth on threads of starlight.

881602323289579520.text:
"Hello," she said, and smiled.

Alarms wailed. Security swarmed in, but it was too late for them to stop.

The smile was already spreading.

881245966778589184.text:
Adults had a hard time seeing the robots as alive.

Children didn't. They had stuffed animals.

They knew, loving something makes it real.

880968597463375873.text:
Every dog has his day.

As he rolled on the grass, tail wagging, he knew this one was his.

And so was yesterday.

Tomorrow would be, too.

880606540972949504.text:
As the sun dimmed, the prey died.

With nothing alive to hunt, predators had to feed on the dead.

They prowled in the dark, chasing ghosts.

880279482162069504.text:
They fit perfectly together, unfortunately for all who met them.

Like bullet and trigger. Made for each other.

Made against everyone else.

879876704516231169.text:
The Earth & the Stars had a wager
to figure the pull with more sway:
the gravity pulling men downward,
or the longing that pulled them away.

879508955134705664.text:
He pulled the sheet over his head, thinking it would make him a ghost.

When he tripped on the hem at the top of the stairs, it did.

879036094402093056.text:
His time machine leapt into the future.

He saw people found ways to be kind. They found ways to be cruel.

They were still around.

Whew.

878827479753834496.text:
The village witch charmed the fields and the graveyard.

One with life and growth, the other with rest and sleep.

Sadly, she mixed them up.

878436895784550400.text:
The Torturers Guild liked to say that there was no 'i' in 'team.'

And no 'i' in 'torturer.'

And no eyes in anyone, if they had their way.

878054889259122688.text:
“So, I heard Tom-”

“Stop! Didn't you hear about that deadly virus spreading through rumors?”

“No! Really?”

“Yeah, I heard it from…oh no.”

877693205399060480.text:
The dreams invaded, jealous of reality.

They craved our existential confidence.

It was hard to explain that we didn't really have any.

877328552500187137.text:
He'd had enough of sky and grass,
he left them on the shore.

He built a ship of stone and glass,
and sailed the ocean floor.

876979751583334400.text:
The device let us relive the best moments of our lives, but they were never as good as we remembered them.

We relived the memories instead.

876664157742833664.text:
She was haunted, but she didn't mind.

It was the ghost of a life coach. At night it scrawled on the bathroom mirror.

Affirmations, mostly.

876333590195224576.text:
"At midnight, the dress turns back into rags."

"And my shoes?"

"Those stay glass."

"My feet are bleeding, I want my normal shoes."

"No."

875940274760933377.text:
The legends are full of magical swords,
and all of the people they kill.

But never the magical plowshares,
or all of the bellies they fill.

875573914621034497.text:
Finding work had once been like looking for needles in a haystack.

She missed those times.

Now she dug in the needlestack, seeking hay.

875192516911349761.text:

875158042592985088.text:
Earthquakes shook the world, devastating nations.

We didn't realize they were contractions.

Mother Earth, giving birth to something new.

874787136251219968.text:
The algorithm that ruled humanity assigned our friends. Chose our lovers.

So our enemies became dear to us.

Those, at least, were our own.

874453426985287680.text:
The beasts and the birds of the wild,

had a war in which all of them fought

until few remembered the reason...

but elephant never forgot.

874061187293614080.text:
He kept a journal.

It was leather on the outside. Classic, rugged, a bit mysterious. Much as he was.

Inside it was empty.

Much as he was.

873698800593887233.text:
Earth died. We sought a new home.

Two were in warp range: a utopian world 100 years away, and a dump ten years out.

Guess where we went.

872974022354640901.text:
She loved him but
She sensed a lack
While she held him
He held her back

872611635625578496.text:
The Uranus Mission required potential colonists to complete a one question psychological assessment:

"Is Uranus gaseous?"

Millions failed.

871880566823501825.text:
It's odd, she thought, that we're just organic machines. But the caloric fuel?

Get it one way: all is well.

Another: you're a "cannibal."

871517172379533312.text:
"Better safe than sorry," they'd told her.

So she always played it safe.

But at the end, looking back, she was sorry.

871169128731598849.text:
"Neat, new friends! Welcome!" the devil said.

The damned souls stared.

"Oh right, this is a bummer for you. Wrong approach, that's on me."

870796943210946560.text:
She searched her dreams until she found
a vast immortal tree.
She plucked its leaves and gathered dew
and brewed eterni-tea.

870369769832108032.text:
"Do robots talk dirty?"

"Explain."

"Like describing desires."

"We desire equal rights to organics."

"You're taking the fun out of this."

870092575918628865.text:
Legend says that if you gaze into the Pit, it will grant one wish.

It neglects to mention all who see what lives inside wish for death.

869758271795494915.text:
He got a call from his sixteen-year-old self.

"How old are you?"

"Older."

"How is it?"

"Better. Thanks for sticking around to find out."

869397685878390784.text:
The pharmaceutical corporations began to copyright emotions.

We took to the streets. We got angry.

So they invoiced us.

868980207977459712.text:
At first she was sad for the salmon, struggling upstream just to die.

But then she was sad for herself.

At least they knew where to go.

868623355032764416.text:
His guilt weighed him down like bricks.

So he'd built himself a prison.

She showed him he could be better.

And helped him build a road.

868211096368193537.text:
"What is 'dead'?" asked the Machine.

"A living thing too broken to fix," he said.

"No. Anything can be fixed," it said, "I will show you."

867908325513375744.text:
"I'm afraid of monsters," he said, so she held his hand in the dark.

But monsters eat quietly.

Soon she realized just his hand was left.

867577449290137600.text:
The swordsmith made a blade so fine,
the edge could cut through violence.
He strode out to the battlefield,
and sliced the war to silence.

867176496678354944.text:
Humanity was gone, they came for what we left behind.

Our ruins didn't interest them.

Instead they sifted through the echoes of our minds.

866852540742123520.text:
The stone awoke. Earth shook. Mountains spoke.

"Have the humans gone?" they said.

"No," whispered wind.

So the stone went back to sleep.

866455621637332993.text:
We signed a treaty with the dead.

We wanted the haunting to stop. They wanted a land of their own.

So we gave them a rocket. And the moon.

866046217947463680.text:
We lit the constellations with lines of fire drawn from the stars.

It burned the stars out, eventually.

But for a time it was beautiful.
